Expectation1: Maintain regular communication with family members
Situation1: The grandmother learns that a family member is dealing with a significant personal crisis.
Situation2: Your I04iend has misunderstood the tone of your text message and replied sounding hurt. You need to call them right now to explain.
Story:
My phone buzzed twice in quick succession. First, a message from my daughter: “Grandma, can you call? Something’s happened with Mark.” My heart clenched—Mark, my grandson, had been struggling lately, and I knew my family expected me to be the steady hand, the one who always checked in and offered comfort. Before I could respond, another notification popped up. It was from Linda, my oldest friend. Her reply to my earlier text was curt, almost cold: “I didn’t realize you felt that way.” I reread my message, realizing how my words could have sounded harsh. Linda and I always prided ourselves on talking things through, never letting misunderstandings fester. I knew she’d be waiting for my call, expecting me to clear the air right away.

I stared at my phone, torn. My family needed me now, but so did Linda. Both expected my attention, my care, my words. I felt the weight of their needs pressing in from both sides, my heart pulled in two directions, unsure which call to make first.
